questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerve is most commonly injured in the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sciatic nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior hip dislocation is most commonly associated with sciatic nerve injury. When injury occurs to the sciatic nerve due to posterior hip dislocation, the common peroneal nerve is usually affected, causing weakness in dorsiflexion of the ankle and loss of toe extension.
  • ➤ Posterior hip dislocation is most commonly associated with sciatic nerve injury.
  • ➤ When injury occurs to the sciatic nerve due to posterior hip dislocation, the common peroneal nerve is usually affected, causing weakness in dorsiflexion of the ankle and loss of toe extension.

questions.text: Which nerve seems to be damaged in the given picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Radial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radial nerve injury is associated with wrist drop i.e., loss of wrist, thumb and fingers of the affected hand, as shown in the image in the question.
  • ➤ Radial nerve injury is associated with wrist drop i.e., loss of wrist, thumb and fingers of the affected hand, as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has sustained an injury and his x-ray is shown. Identify the best choice which marks the delayed set of complications seen in this injury?
questions.correct_answer: B. Damage to ulnar nerve, non-union
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Damage to ulnar nerve, non-union

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to ulnar nerve, non-union is a well-established delayed complication, particularly in pediatric supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: The following clinical sign is elicited in patient after an operation. Which of the following nerve is injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Median nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Median nerve injury at the level of elbow is associated with pointing index deformity of the hand i.e., the loss flexion of IP joints of index & middle fingers.
  • ➤ Median nerve injury at the level of elbow is associated with pointing index deformity of the hand i.e., the loss flexion of IP joints of index & middle fingers.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Charcot arthropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Charcot arthropathy is commonly seen in diabetic patients with a differentiating feature of presence of no pain sensation in the affected joint. There is a presence of swelling and restriction of movement. The radiological findings shows features similar to osteoarthritis.
  • ➤ Charcot arthropathy is commonly seen in diabetic patients with a differentiating feature of presence of no pain sensation in the affected joint.
  • ➤ There is a presence of swelling and restriction of movement.
  • ➤ The radiological findings shows features similar to osteoarthritis.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Compression plating is a surgical technique used in the internal fixation of fractures. It involves the use of a specially designed plate and screws to stabilize fractured bone segments by applying compression across the fracture site.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Procedure: During compression plating, the plate is applied to the surface of the bone, typically on the tension side of the fracture. Screws are inserted through the plate and into the bone to hold the fractured fragments in alignment. The screws can be tightened to compress the fracture fragments together, promoting healing.
  • • Procedure:
  • • Indications: Compression plating is suitable for fractures where stable fixation is required, especially in cases of comminuted fractures or fractures in load-bearing bones.
  • • Indications:
  • • Advantages: Provides rigid fixation, allows early mobilization and weight-bearing, promotes direct bone healing, and reduces the risk of malunion or nonunion.
  • • Advantages:
  • • Considerations: Careful preoperative planning is necessary to determine the appropriate plate size and screw placement. Postoperative rehabilitation may involve physical therapy to restore strength and function.
  • • Considerations:
  • • Option C. Internal fixation:
  • • Option C. Internal fixation:
  • • Explanation: Internal fixation refers to the surgical technique of stabilizing fractured bones using implants such as plates, screws, rods, or nails that are placed inside the body. Procedure: The choice of implant depends on the location and type of fracture. Plates and screws are commonly used for fractures near the surface of bones, while rods or nails are used for long bone fractures such as femoral or tibial fractures. Indications: Internal fixation is indicated for fractures that cannot be adequately stabilized with external methods (like casting) alone. It provides immediate stability to fractured bones, allowing for early mobilization and faster healing. Advantages: Provides rigid stabilization, allows for early mobilization and rehabilitation, reduces the risk of malunion or nonunion, and promotes faster recovery. Considerations: Potential complications include implant failure, infection, and damage to surrounding tissues during surgery. Careful surgical technique and postoperative monitoring are essential to minimize risks.
  • • Explanation: Internal fixation refers to the surgical technique of stabilizing fractured bones using implants such as plates, screws, rods, or nails that are placed inside the body.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Procedure: The choice of implant depends on the location and type of fracture. Plates and screws are commonly used for fractures near the surface of bones, while rods or nails are used for long bone fractures such as femoral or tibial fractures.
  • • Procedure:
  • • Indications: Internal fixation is indicated for fractures that cannot be adequately stabilized with external methods (like casting) alone. It provides immediate stability to fractured bones, allowing for early mobilization and faster healing.
  • • Indications:
  • • Advantages: Provides rigid stabilization, allows for early mobilization and rehabilitation, reduces the risk of malunion or nonunion, and promotes faster recovery.
  • • Advantages:
  • • Considerations: Potential complications include implant failure, infection, and damage to surrounding tissues during surgery. Careful surgical technique and postoperative monitoring are essential to minimize risks.
  • • Considerations:
  • • Option D. K-wire fixation:
  • • Option D. K-wire fixation:
  • • Explanation: K-wire fixation involves the use of stainless steel wires (Kirschner wires or K-wires) to stabilize fractures or hold bone fragments in place. Procedure: K-wires are inserted percutaneously (through the skin) and across the fracture site or bone fragments. They can be used alone or in combination with other fixation methods such as casting or external fixation. Indications: K-wires are commonly used for simple fractures, temporary fixation, or in cases where other fixation methods are not suitable or necessary. Advantages: Minimally invasive, quick and easy to insert, cost-effective, and useful for maintaining alignment in certain types of fractures. Considerations: K-wires provide less stability compared to plates or screws and are usually temporary. They may need to be removed once the fracture has healed sufficiently, and there is a risk of pin tract infection or migration.
  • • Explanation: K-wire fixation involves the use of stainless steel wires (Kirschner wires or K-wires) to stabilize fractures or hold bone fragments in place.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Procedure: K-wires are inserted percutaneously (through the skin) and across the fracture site or bone fragments. They can be used alone or in combination with other fixation methods such as casting or external fixation.
  • • Procedure:
  • • Indications: K-wires are commonly used for simple fractures, temporary fixation, or in cases where other fixation methods are not suitable or necessary.
  • • Indications:
  • • Advantages: Minimally invasive, quick and easy to insert, cost-effective, and useful for maintaining alignment in certain types of fractures.
  • • Advantages:
  • • Considerations: K-wires provide less stability compared to plates or screws and are usually temporary. They may need to be removed once the fracture has healed sufficiently, and there is a risk of pin tract infection or migration.
  • • Considerations:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image is of a displaced transverse fracture of patella. The treatment suitable in this case is tension band wiring.

questions.text: Bone Mineral Density Screening should be performed in which of the following patients?

options.label: A
options.text: If you are woman of age 65 or older

options.label: B
options.text: If you are a man of age 70 or older

options.label: C
options.text: If you break a bone after the age of 50

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BMD screening is recommended for women aged 65 years and older, men aged 70 years and older, and individuals who experience a fragility fracture after the age of 50. These screenings help in evaluating bone density, assessing fracture risk, and guiding management strategies to prevent osteoporotic fractures.

questions.text: Assertion : Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. Reason : Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.

options.label: A
options.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT. Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.
  • ➤ When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • ➤ Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bending forward

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test. A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.
  • ➤ Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • ➤ A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) DISH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.
  • ➤ The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic shoulder pain and difficulty lifting objects overhead. Physical examination reveals tenderness and weakness in the affected shoulder. Which of the following condition is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rotator Cuff tear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This condition commonly presents with these symptoms due to the mechanical disruption of the rotator cuff tendons, leading to pain, tenderness, and weakness, particularly with activities that require overhead movement.

questions.text: Counter force brace is used for:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Tennis elbow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow. This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.
  • ➤ Counter force brace is used for the rehabilitation of tennis elbow.
  • ➤ This brace dissipates the forces away from the injured tissue to the surrounding non-injured area.

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture? Compartment syndrome is rare. Immediate debridement should be done. Tibia is the most common long bone involved. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.correct_answer: B. I, II & III are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure. These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound. Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.
  • ➤ In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • ➤ These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • ➤ Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: A mother with history of vaginal delivery 2 days ago complains of numbness in lateral aspects of thigh. Which nerve is likely to have been damaged?
questions.correct_answer: B. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh supplies sensation to the lateral thigh, and injury or compression of this nerve can lead to numbness or altered sensation specifically in the lateral aspect of the thigh, a condition known as meralgia paresthetica.

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:

options.label: A
options.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decreased response to analgesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complain of no reduction in the pain symptoms.
  • ➤ The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complain of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scaphoid fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.
  • ➤ The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: What is the type of fracture shown in the X-ray of left shoulder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neer classification grade 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neer classification grade, this classification specifically describes proximal humerus fractures involving the surgical neck with severe displacement and comminution.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur. The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.
  • ➤ The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • ➤ The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

questions.text: A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) III, IV are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.
  • ➤ Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents to the office with a 6-week history of left hip pain with ambulation. Initial ESR 120. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Resection of the proximal femur and reconstruction with a proximal femur replacement

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple myeloma panel and CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis

options.label: D
options.text: CT and MRI of the femur

questions.correct_answer: C. Multiple myeloma panel and CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Multiple myeloma panel and CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate next step is conducting a multiple myeloma panel and a CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis. The reason is that multiple myeloma can present with bone pain, especially in older individuals, and the workup should include evaluating for lytic bone lesions or other systemic involvement, which may not be readily apparent in local imaging like a femur-specific CT or MRI.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male complaints of high-grade fever, decreased appetite and pain right hip. On examination, he has dehydration/tenderness in Scarpa’s triangle/ swelling in right hip region, flexion, abduction and external rotation at hip/absent movements in right hip region. On X-ray, there is mild increase in medial joint space. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Septic arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septic arthritis presents with systemic symptoms, localized joint findings, and radiographic changes indicative of joint effusion. Immediate evaluation and management, including joint aspiration for culture, are crucial in suspected cases of septic arthritis to prevent joint destruction and systemic complications.

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:

options.label: A
options.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius

options.label: B
options.text: Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.correct_answer: B. Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture. Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.
  • ➤ The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture.
  • ➤ Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.

questions.text: In SCFE, the displacement of epiphyseal plate of femur occurs: Medially Laterally Posteriorly Rotationally No displacement
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SCFE, the epiphysis of the femur slips posteriorly and inferiorly (downward and backward) relative to the femoral neck, but the growth plate remains intact. This results in a slipped position without full displacement of the epiphysis from the femoral neck. Therefore, the most accurate description is "no displacement", since the bone doesn't detach, but rather shifts in a particular direction.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Distal humerus fracture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Distal fibula fractures are less common in children compared to adults. They typically occur due to twisting injuries or direct trauma to the ankle region.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Clinical features: Children with distal fibula fractures present with pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight on the affected leg.
  • • Clinical features:
  • • Management: Treatment depends on the stability of the fracture. Stable fractures may be treated with casting, while unstable fractures may require surgical fixation.
  • • Management:
  • • Option D. Distal femur fracture: Distal femur fractures in children can have various fracture patterns, including supracondylar fractures, or fractures of any pattern from the Salter-Harris classification. Salter-Harris II fractures of the distal femur are the most common pattern in children. Even though distal femur fractures are relatively uncommon injuries, they can have significant implications for limb alignment and future growth. Distal femur fractures in children are typically related to trauma, such as falls, motor vehicle accidents, or contact sports. Patients have pain, swelling about the knee, deformity, and an inability to bear weight on the affected leg. Closed manipulation and casting is an option in displaced fractures, although they have significant potential for instability, which could lead to malunion. Internal fixation is the most commonly chosen treatments.
  • • Option D. Distal femur fracture:
  • • Salter-Harris II fractures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fish tail deformity is a rare complication of distal humerus fracture in children.

questions.text: In case of meniscal tear, in which of the following zones the healing is best seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Red zone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone. Any injury in this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.
  • ➤ The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone.
  • ➤ Any injury in this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.

questions.text: Joint erosion is not a feature in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: Following is not a part of Ortolani test:

options.label: A
options.text: Examiner's thumb rests on the medial thigh

options.label: B
options.text: Examiner's finger lie on the greater trochanter

options.label: C
options.text: Hips are flexed to 90 degrees and gently abducted

options.label: D
options.text: Jerk is given to the knee to dislocate the femur head

questions.correct_answer: D. Jerk is given to the knee to dislocate the femur head
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Jerk is given to the knee to dislocate the femur head

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Ortolani’s Test, the hips and knees are flexed to 90-degree, then an anterior pressure is applied over the greater trochanter and the examiner gently abduct the leg with thumbs. The examiner’s fingers lies over the greater trochanter & thumb rests over the medial thigh. If the hip is dislocated, a distinctive clunk will be heard as the hip relocates, which makes the test positive.
  • ➤ In Ortolani’s Test, the hips and knees are flexed to 90-degree, then an anterior pressure is applied over the greater trochanter and the examiner gently abduct the leg with thumbs.
  • ➤ The examiner’s fingers lies over the greater trochanter & thumb rests over the medial thigh.
  • ➤ If the hip is dislocated, a distinctive clunk will be heard as the hip relocates, which makes the test positive.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffers from road traffic accident where a car run-over his right leg. On examination, his vitals are stable and general physical examination is okay. His right leg is crushed with exposed muscles and bones. The debate about limbs survival can be resolved to an extent by MESS score. It includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Nerve injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The MESS score used as a predictor for limb salvage after crush injuries comprises of monitoring of BP, Distal circulation and know about the history of trauma including the Velocity of trauma.
  • ➤ The MESS score used as a predictor for limb salvage after crush injuries comprises of monitoring of BP, Distal circulation and know about the history of trauma including the Velocity of trauma.
  • ➤ The Nerve injury is not included in it.
  • ➤ The Nerve injury is not included in it.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with rickets is on calcium supplements and has a foot deformity. The child will be referred to a surgeon for the correction of the deformity when:

options.label: B
options.text: Serum vitamin D levels are normal

questions.correct_answer: C. Growth plate healing becomes normal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Growth plate healing becomes normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • ➤ The appropriate timing for surgical intervention based on the normalization of growth plate healing rather than relying solely on normal serum calcium, vitamin D levels, or alkaline phosphatase levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about osteoarthritis?

options.label: D
options.text: Narrowing of the joint space occurs

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inflammation of synovial joints

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoarthritis is primarily characterized by degeneration of the joint cartilage and changes in the underlying bone. Unlike rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis is not characterized by significant inflammation of the synovial membrane. Instead, it involves a more gradual and wear-and-tear type of joint damage.
  • ➤ Osteoarthritis is primarily characterized by degeneration of the joint cartilage and changes in the underlying bone.
  • ➤ Unlike rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis is not characterized by significant inflammation of the synovial membrane.
  • ➤ Instead, it involves a more gradual and wear-and-tear type of joint damage.

questions.text: Ottawa ankle rules are used to:

options.label: C
options.text: Decide on need of X-rays for possible fracture

options.label: D
options.text: Decide on immediate vs delayed treatment of ankle dislocation

questions.correct_answer: C. Decide on need of X-rays for possible fracture
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Decide on need of X-rays for possible fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ottawa ankle rules are used to decide the need of immediate x-rays for the possible fracture of the ankle. If any of the 5 criterias are fulfilled, the patient requires an immediate x-ray investigation to take further treatment actions without any delay. The criterias are:
  • ➤ Ottawa ankle rules are used to decide the need of immediate x-rays for the possible fracture of the ankle.
  • ➤ If any of the 5 criterias are fulfilled, the patient requires an immediate x-ray investigation to take further treatment actions without any delay.
  • ➤ The criterias are:
  • ➤ The criterias are:
  • ➤ Pain around the malleolus Inability to take weight on the ankle immediately after the injury Inability to take four steps in Emergency Department Bony tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the medial or lateral malleolus.
  • ➤ Pain around the malleolus
  • ➤ Inability to take weight on the ankle immediately after the injury
  • ➤ Inability to take four steps in Emergency Department
  • ➤ Bony tenderness at the posterior edge or tip of the medial or lateral malleolus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with history of pathological fracture of neck of femur. She has elevated ALP and N – Telopeptide. Her DEXA scan confirmed a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Which of the following would be raised?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's history of osteoporosis and increased bone resorption (as indicated by elevated ALP and N-telopeptide) suggests increased osteoclast activity. The best biomarker is Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), as it is a marker of osteoclast activity and bone resorption.

questions.text: A young lady after intense workout, lifting heavy weights, presents to you with a lower back ache involving right hip and radiating to right ankle. MRI shows the following finding. What nerve root is likely to get involved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) L5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The symptoms described—lower back ache, radiating to the hip, and down to the ankle—most closely align with L5 nerve root involvement. The L5 root typically presents with pain that radiates down the lateral leg and ankle.

questions.text: Post contrast MRI of the spine of a 40-year-old man who presented with chronic back pain has been shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pott’s spine or spinal tuberculosis is the most likely diagnosis when there is chronic back pain and vertebral body destruction seen on MRI, along with possible paraspinal abscesses or spinal deformities.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with a mushroom like tumour in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features will help the clinician to identify a malignant transformation?

options.label: A
options.text: Initially growth of the tumour was away from the joint, now tumour growth is towards the joint

options.label: B
options.text: Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm

options.label: C
options.text: Tumour does not have malignant transformation

options.label: D
options.text: Tumour is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most concerning feature for malignant transformation in this case is the 2 cm hyaline cap thickness , as cartilage caps larger than 1.5 cm to 2 cm can indicate the potential for the development of chondrosarcoma .

  • ➤ cartilage caps
  • ➤ chondrosarcoma

questions.text: What is the principle of TENS which is used for alleviating pain around joints and nerve pain?
questions.correct_answer: A. Gate theory of pain control
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gate theory of pain control

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The TENS modality alleviates neurogenic pain by the principle of pain gate mechanism.
  • ➤ The TENS modality alleviates neurogenic pain by the principle of pain gate mechanism.

questions.text: Meyer pedicle graft used for:

options.label: A
options.text: Fracture through neck of the talus

options.label: C
options.text: Fracture through the waist of the scaphoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Non-union fracture neck of femur
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non-union fracture neck of femur

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Meyer pedicle graft is specifically designed to treat non-union fractures of the femoral neck, particularly in cases where there is a concern for avascular necrosis (AVN). The graft provides vascularized bone to the femoral head, helping to restore blood flow and promote healing.

questions.text: Bony ankylosis is noticed in case of:
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Pyogenic arthritis

questions.text: A pole vaulter had a fall during pole vaulting and had paralysis of the arm. Which of the following investigations gives the best recovery prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electromyography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electromyography (EMG) gives the best recovery prognosis in a case of arm paralysis following a fall during pole vaulting. EMG directly assesses nerve and muscle function, providing insights into the extent of nerve injury and potential for recovery.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and discharges pus from right leg for 3 months. Following is the radiograph of the child. Identify the labelled structured:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Involucrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called cloaca . Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called cloaca .
  • ➤ involucrum
  • ➤ cloaca
  • ➤ Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ Sequestrum

questions.text: A football player had a twisting injury of the knee with no clinical bony injury. Which test is being performed here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lachman test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lachman test specifically evaluates the integrity of the ACL and is particularly valuable in the setting of acute injury when other tests might be less reliable.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most sensitive MRI sequence for detecting early cartilage damage in osteoarthritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Proton Density (PD) Weighted Imaging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proton Density (PD) weighted imaging is generally considered the most sensitive for detecting early cartilage damage in osteoarthritis. It provides a clear image of cartilage structure and can detect subtle changes more effectively than T1-weighted, T2-weighted, or STIR imaging. PD-weighted imaging balances the contrast between cartilage and surrounding tissues, making it a valuable tool in early diagnosis and assessment of cartilage health.
  • ➤ Proton Density (PD) weighted imaging

questions.text: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Madura mycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis. The filamentous structures observed in KOH smear are the Filamentous Bacteria like Nocardia, Actinomadura madurae.
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the smear result is suggestive of Madura mycosis.
  • ➤ The filamentous structures observed in KOH smear are the Filamentous Bacteria like Nocardia, Actinomadura madurae.

questions.text: For Tuberculosis of spine, best diagnostic modality is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CT-guided biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiological diagnosis in case of infections like tuberculosis of spine is never diagnostic. Tissue diagnosis is always diagnostic. Infections and tumours can mimic each other; thus, culture is gold standard for infection and histopathology is gold standard for tumours. So, the rule is, culture all biopsies and biopsy all cultures .
  • ➤ Radiological diagnosis in case of infections like tuberculosis of spine is never diagnostic.
  • ➤ Tissue diagnosis is always diagnostic.
  • ➤ Infections and tumours can mimic each other; thus, culture is gold standard for infection and histopathology is gold standard for tumours.
  • ➤ culture is gold standard
  • ➤ So, the rule is, culture all biopsies and biopsy all cultures .
  • ➤ culture all biopsies and biopsy all cultures

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anaesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anaesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: A child is unable to carry out movements of pronation-supination since childhood due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Radio-ulnar synostosis

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radio-ulnar synostosis directly leads to an inability to perform pronation and supination due to the fusion of the radius and ulna.
  • ➤ Radio-ulnar synostosis directly leads to an inability to perform pronation and supination due to the fusion of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic osteomyelitis is the most likely based on the history of trauma, long duration of symptoms, and the radiological findings showing deformity and bone destruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.
  • ➤ Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: Spinal injury with no radiological finding is commonly seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spinal injury with no radiological findings is more commonly seen in children due to the flexibility of the spine, the developing bones, and the increased likelihood of ligamentous or soft tissue injuries that do not show up on standard imaging.

questions.text: Locking compression plating is commonly indicated in which of the following fracture types?

options.label: B
options.text: Transverse or oblique fractures of long bones

questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Periarticular fractures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Locking Compression Plate (LCP) is most commonly indicated in periarticular fractures because these fractures involve the joint and require precise, stable fixation to prevent complications like joint instability and improper healing. LCPs offer excellent biomechanical advantages in such cases due to their ability to provide strong, stable fixation, especially in complex or osteoporotic bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is an intra-articular fracture?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All three fractures— Barton’s , Bennett’s , and Pilon fractures —are intra-articular fractures because they involve the joint surface and can affect joint function.
  • ➤ Barton’s
  • ➤ Bennett’s
  • ➤ Pilon fractures

questions.text: Absence of lamina dura in the alveolus occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hyperparathyroidism, the increased activity of parathyroid hormone (PTH) results in bone resorption, including the alveolar bone surrounding the teeth. This process can lead to the loss of lamina dura, which is the dense cortical bone lining the tooth socket seen on dental radiographs. Therefore, the absence of lamina dura in the alveolus is a characteristic finding in hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: The following pelvic X-ray was seen in a patient. All the following signs will be present except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gaenslen’s Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaenslen’s test is a clinical maneuver used in physical examination to assess sacroiliac joint dysfunction and is not visible on a pelvic X-ray. Gaenslen’s test does not belong as it is not visible on X-ray but is a clinical assessment for sacroiliac joint issues.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female comes with low back pain. following is seen on CT scan. Sr. Ca is 7mg/dL, ALP is elevated. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteomalacia is the diagnosis based on low serum calcium, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and the clinical presentation of bone pain.

questions.text: The following muscles cause inversion of foot except:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Peroneus Longus

questions.text: Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in which type of collagen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Collagen 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in type 1 collagen. It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • ➤ Osteogenesis imperfecta has abnormality in type 1 collagen.
  • ➤ It is a genetic disorder of connective tissue determined by quantitative qualitative defect in type I collagen formation.
  • ➤ So, there is alteration in the structural integrity, or a reduction in the total amount of type I collagen, one of the major components of fibrillar connective tissue in skin, ligaments, bones, sclera, and teeth.

questions.text: Salt pepper skull is a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Primary hyperparathyroidism

  • ➤ Salt and pepper skull is a radiographic feature of primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A patient who used to work out regularly at the gym gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AVN of hip (Avascular Necrosis of the Hip) fits well with the clinical presentation of gradually worsening hip pain aggravated by physical activities like squatting, and the radiographic findings are typical for AVN. This diagnosis should prompt consideration of further imaging and management to prevent progression to femoral head collapse and hip joint degeneration.

questions.text: Post-traumatic osteomyelitis causing organism is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most common cause of post-traumatic osteomyelitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Streptococcus pyogenes, E. coli, and Pseudomonas are less commonly implicated, though they can cause osteomyelitis in certain scenarios or when there are specific risk factors.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.
  • ➤ The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with a history of hip pain and a recent fall resulting in a fracture. She has a known history of osteoporosis. MRI of the hip reveals a subtrochanteric femur fracture. During surgical planning, you note that the fracture is associated with a significant loss of cortical bone integrity. What is the most appropriate surgical management for this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Open reduction and internal fixation with plates

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intramedullary nail fixation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intramedullary nail fixation is the most appropriate surgical management for a subtrochanteric femur fracture in a patient with significant bone integrity loss.

questions.text: An X-ray is presented showing a lateral view of the knee joint in a 30-year-old male who has sustained a sports injury. The X-ray reveals a "double contour" sign on the femur with a notable defect in the articular cartilage. The patient reports pain during weight-bearing activities and has a history of joint effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteochondritis dissecans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteochondritis dissecans is the most likely diagnosis due to the characteristic imaging findings and the associated symptoms.

questions.text: Thurston Holland sign is seen in
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Type II epiphyseal injury

questions.text: In patients with severe osteoarthritis, which of the following is considered a contraindication for arthroplasty?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Active infection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Active infection is indeed a contraindication for arthroplasty. Performing surgery on a joint with an active infection can lead to further complications, including the spread of infection, poor healing, and implant failure. It is crucial to treat any infections prior to considering joint replacement surgery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Obesity: Obesity is not an absolute contraindication for arthroplasty but rather a relative contraindication. While obesity increases the risk of complications such as infection, wound healing issues, and implant failure, many surgeons will still proceed with the surgery if the benefits outweigh the risks. Weight loss prior to surgery may be encouraged to improve outcomes.
  • • Option A. Obesity:
  • • Option C. Previous knee surgery: Previous knee surgery is not necessarily a contraindication for arthroplasty. Many patients who have undergone prior surgeries, such as arthroscopy or ligament repair, can still be candidates for joint replacement. The decision depends on the condition of the joint and the specific surgical history. However, previous surgeries may complicate the procedure or affect the recovery process.
  • • Option C. Previous knee surgery:
  • • Option D. Moderate renal impairment: Moderate renal impairment is generally not an absolute contraindication for arthroplasty. While it may increase the risk of perioperative complications, many patients with moderate renal impairment can still safely undergo surgery with appropriate management and monitoring. The surgical team will typically assess the patient's overall health and kidney function prior to proceeding.
  • • Option D. Moderate renal impairment:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active infection is the primary contraindication due to the high risk of complications if surgery is performed in the presence of infection.

questions.text: The earliest radiological sign in Pott’s disease is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Narrowing of intervertebral disc space
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Narrowing of intervertebral disc space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign of Pott's disease is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space . This sign occurs due to the initial infection and inflammation in the disc space before more advanced features like vertebral erosion or collapse develop.
  • ➤ The earliest radiological sign of Pott's disease is the narrowing of the intervertebral disc space .
  • ➤ narrowing of the intervertebral disc space
  • ➤ This sign occurs due to the initial infection and inflammation in the disc space before more advanced features like vertebral erosion or collapse develop.

questions.text: What is not true about anterior cruciate ligament?

options.label: A
options.text: It begins just behind the anterior horn of lateral meniscus on tibia

options.label: C
options.text: It provides proprioceptive inputs to knee

questions.correct_answer: A. It begins just behind the anterior horn of lateral meniscus on tibia
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) It begins just behind the anterior horn of lateral meniscus on tibia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACL begins from the tibial plateau between and anterior to the intercondylar eminences. It is taut in extension. It provides proprioceptive inputs to knee. It is an extra-synovial structure.
  • ➤ ACL begins from the tibial plateau between and anterior to the intercondylar eminences.
  • ➤ It is taut in extension.
  • ➤ It provides proprioceptive inputs to knee.
  • ➤ It is an extra-synovial structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common muscle to be congenitally absent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pectoralis major

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies. The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.
  • ➤ While congenital absence of certain muscles is associated with specific conditions (e.g., Poland syndrome for pectoralis major), the absence of muscles like semimembranosus, teres minor, or gluteus maximus is uncommon and may be part of rare congenital anomalies.
  • ➤ The most common muscle to be congenitally absent among the options provided is the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Which is the most common shoulder dislocation in epileptic patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation in epileptic patients. The violent, involuntary movements during a seizure are most likely to cause this type of dislocation.
  • ➤ Posterior dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation in epileptic patients.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of sudden increase in pain in osteochondroma, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Degenerative changes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Degenerative changes are a gradual process and are less likely to cause a sudden increase in pain compared to complications like sarcomatous change, fracture, or bursitis, which can result in more immediate and severe symptoms.
  • ➤ Degenerative changes are a gradual process and are less likely to cause a sudden increase in pain compared to complications like sarcomatous change, fracture, or bursitis, which can result in more immediate and severe symptoms.

questions.text: All are seen in anterior shoulder dislocation except:

Ans. A) Elevated anterior axillary fold

  • ➤ In the anterior shoulder dislocation, the anterior axillary fold is at a lower level. The Dugas and Hamilton ruler tests are positive. There is an increased vertical circumference of the axilla as compared to the normal side – Callaway’s test.

questions.text: Increased bone density with hyperostosis seen in skeletal fluorosis is likely to occur when fluorine concentration in drinking water is above:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 10 ppm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The threshold for significant skeletal fluorosis, particularly with manifestations like hyperostosis (increased bone density and bone growth), is widely cited as being at or above 10 ppm with chronic exposure. The concentrations represent a spectrum of severity: < 4 ppm: Generally safe for skeletal health (though dental fluorosis can occur at ~1.5-2 ppm). 4-8 ppm: Risk of early, mild skeletal fluorosis with long-term exposure, possibly subtle bone density increases. ≥ 10 ppm: High likelihood of moderate to severe skeletal fluorosis, characterized by prominent increased bone density and hyperostosis , leading to functional impairment over time. ≥ 15-20 ppm: Severe and often crippling skeletal fluorosis with widespread and debilitating hyperostosis.
  • ➤ The threshold for significant skeletal fluorosis, particularly with manifestations like hyperostosis (increased bone density and bone growth), is widely cited as being at or above 10 ppm with chronic exposure.
  • ➤ 10 ppm
  • ➤ The concentrations represent a spectrum of severity: < 4 ppm: Generally safe for skeletal health (though dental fluorosis can occur at ~1.5-2 ppm). 4-8 ppm: Risk of early, mild skeletal fluorosis with long-term exposure, possibly subtle bone density increases. ≥ 10 ppm: High likelihood of moderate to severe skeletal fluorosis, characterized by prominent increased bone density and hyperostosis , leading to functional impairment over time. ≥ 15-20 ppm: Severe and often crippling skeletal fluorosis with widespread and debilitating hyperostosis.
  • ➤ The concentrations represent a spectrum of severity:
  • ➤ < 4 ppm: Generally safe for skeletal health (though dental fluorosis can occur at ~1.5-2 ppm). 4-8 ppm: Risk of early, mild skeletal fluorosis with long-term exposure, possibly subtle bone density increases. ≥ 10 ppm: High likelihood of moderate to severe skeletal fluorosis, characterized by prominent increased bone density and hyperostosis , leading to functional impairment over time. ≥ 15-20 ppm: Severe and often crippling skeletal fluorosis with widespread and debilitating hyperostosis.
  • ➤ < 4 ppm: Generally safe for skeletal health (though dental fluorosis can occur at ~1.5-2 ppm).
  • ➤ < 4 ppm:
  • ➤ 4-8 ppm: Risk of early, mild skeletal fluorosis with long-term exposure, possibly subtle bone density increases.
  • ➤ 4-8 ppm:
  • ➤ ≥ 10 ppm: High likelihood of moderate to severe skeletal fluorosis, characterized by prominent increased bone density and hyperostosis , leading to functional impairment over time.
  • ➤ ≥ 10 ppm:
  • ➤ hyperostosis
  • ➤ ≥ 15-20 ppm: Severe and often crippling skeletal fluorosis with widespread and debilitating hyperostosis.
  • ➤ ≥ 15-20 ppm:
